description: In the 1890s Louis Comfort Tiffany began using his opalescent Favrile glass to produce lamps, the form for which he would become most famous. As the artistic director of Tiffany Studios, he approved all patterns but created relatively few lamps himself. Clara Driscoll, head of the Women’s Glass Cutting Department, designed the majority of the firm’s lamps, including, likely, this one.
artist_info:
Design attributed to Clara Pierce Wolcott Driscoll (American
1861–1944)
Tiffany Studios (American, 1902–32)
Corona, New York
title: Lamp with “Hanging Head Dragonfly” Shade and “Mosaic and Turtleback” Base
